results.title: Hello
results.brief_description: ‘Hello’ is it me you’re looking for?’ A wildly imaginative love story about love across the digital-analogue divides. Can an almost obsolete cassette head speak the language of love with only fast forward and rewind to work with?

results.title: Decent exposure
results.brief_description:
Decent Exposure evolved from the belief that art should be confronting, stimulating to those who view it. The video was an attempt to take the concept and give it concrete form. The basic plot is that art escapes en-masse from galleries and confronts people on the streets. Its left up to the cops to stop the “escapee” art from terrorising the population but to do that they have to capture the ringleader, The Expert.
The Expert is a sculpture of an art critic, a middle aged man in underpants (based on Peter Corlett’s The Connoisseur, currently in the Ian Potter Museum) struck in a judgemental pose as though he is forming a pompous opinion of an artwork.
The story was set in contemporary Melbourne (1990). Those dreary consumerists who now dominate the inner suburbs were already beginning to invade our fragile but energetic Fitzroy and St Kilda art communities. The dead hand of conservatism and bureaucratic centralisation was already being felt.
The plot ambitiously, but rather awkwardly, strove to shout to the world that, ‘the Emperor has no clothes”. In 1990 the Pyramid bank crash had just happened. The government is so on the nose electorally that party officials start moves to recruit The Expert, who has become a charismatic figure to the media. They intend him to replace the Treasurer.
Somehow I convinced journalist Jim Schembri (who bore a striking resemblance to the sculpture) that playing The Expert would be a good idea. His accepted his costume (a pair of Y front undies) with a look of trepidation.
The highlight was Jim running through the St Kilda Esplanade market, with the camera hidden 50 metres away, on a busy Sunday morning proclaiming to those he ‘confronted’ that he was a sculpture who was, ‘living, breathing art” - the great thing is that Jim was, for that moment, being accurate.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.brief_description:
‘Harry She’llberight’ is a lazy farmer, stuck in the ‘old ways’ of chemical spraying. He provides a ‘worst case scenario’ of chemical spray use. A representative of the Vistorian Department of Agriculture assists Harry in modern spraying techniques, equipment and safety. Along the way we are introduced to different spray epuipment and how it operates away from Harry’s farm.

Harry is a comical character and he eventually gets his act together as the film progresses.

Opening contains nice shots of people picking lettuce and scens inside of a vegetable market.

Good cartoon-like illustrations about chemical spraying safety.

results.title: The Nature of paradise
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble
results.brief_description:
Three women - Trish Molloy (artist), Monique La Fontaine (artist), Sharon Wiggan (law student) - tell their stories, each from a personal perspective, of their relationship and connection to the Western Australian north-west coastal town of Broome. Trish and Monique are travellers who have separately found their way to Broome and stayed and Sharon is an Aboriginal Australian who was brought up in Broome, left to study in Perth and who has now returned home to Broome. The documentary explores each woman’s emotional and spiritual attachment to the town, to their surrounding environment and their kinship with the people of Broome and with each other. Evocative and beautifully photographed by Veronica Iacono, and sensitively scripted and directed by Lucinda Gamble, “The Nature of paradise” is stunningly rich in images and colour, of reds and blues, of the earth, sky and the ocean and is accompanied by an ambient musical soundtrack, “Free diving” written and performed by Lorrei
Coffin. Interspersed throughout the documentary are images of both Trish and Monique’s paintings which reflect their transitional journey to this place called “paradise”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Lucinda Gamble

results.title: Cross my heart
results.creator_credit: Andrew Wiseman, Jocelyn Moorhouse, David Swann and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Two women attending a friend’s funeral who died from cancer vow to quit smoking, cold turkey. There are obstacles in their way however, including a sister who has just split up with her partner, her son in tow. They instil a no smoking policy in the house with penalties for those who break the rules. Features salient points about the ill effects of smoking and the side effects you can expect when quitting. Cast includes: Marilyn O’Donnell, Parthena Amanatidis, Tamasin Ramsay, Brian Nankervis.
